articles.headline: Continuing Unemployment Is Predicted by Fed Chief
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned that high unemployment and reluctance of banks to make loans were likely to slow recovery.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned that high unemployment and reluctance of banks to make loans were likely to slow recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned on Monday that high unemployment and a continued reluctance by banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year.

articles.headline: Taint of Corruption Is No Barrier to U.S. Visa
articles.snippet: The U.S. is open for Teodoro Nguema Obiang, the son of Equatorial Guinea’s ruler, despite evidence of corruption.
articles.abstract: The U.S. is open for Teodoro Nguema Obiang, the son of Equatorial Guinea’s ruler, despite evidence of corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several times a year, Teodoro Nguema Obiang arrives at the doorstep of the United States from his home in Equatorial Guinea, on his way to his $35 million estate in Malibu, Calif., his fleet of luxury cars, his speedboats and private jet. And he is always let into the country.

articles.headline: Inspectors Fear Iran Is Hiding Nuclear Plants
articles.snippet: International inspectors raised questions about whether Iran has concealed other nuclear factories in addition to the recently discovered site in Qum.
articles.abstract: International inspectors raised questions about whether Iran has concealed other nuclear factories in addition to the recently discovered site in Qum.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  International inspectors who gained access to Iran’s newly revealed underground nuclear enrichment plant voiced strong suspicions in a report on Monday that the country was concealing other atomic facilities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Airline Tests Retail Sales at 35,000 Feet
articles.snippet: “Anytime you have customers who are captive, who have nothing better to do, they’ll shop,” says a marketing professor. And who’s more captive than an airline passenger?
articles.abstract: “Anytime you have customers who are captive, who have nothing better to do, they’ll shop,” says a marketing professor. And who’s more captive than an airline passenger?
articles.lead_paragraph: Air travelers in the United States are already paying for sandwiches and drinks, pillows and headsets. So, as airlines look for more ways to help their bottom lines, they have started asking the next logical question: Why not sell limousine services or even tickets to Broadway shows?

articles.headline: Capital Waits as Budget Chief Crunches Numbers
articles.snippet: Both sides of the health care debate in Washington are waiting to hear what Douglas W. Elmendorf has to say.
articles.abstract: Both sides of the health care debate in Washington are waiting to hear what Douglas W. Elmendorf has to say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Most people have never heard of Douglas W. Elmendorf. But all of official Washington is waiting to hear what he has to say.

articles.headline: Audit Faults New York Fed in A.I.G. Bailout
articles.snippet: Officials managing the bailout of the insurance giant may have overpaid other banks to wind down business relationships with A.I.G., Neil Barofsky, the bailout inspector, says.
articles.abstract: Officials managing the bailout of the insurance giant may have overpaid other banks to wind down business relationships with A.I.G., Neil Barofsky, the bailout inspector, says.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York gave up much of its power in high-pressure negotiations with the American International Group’s trading partners last year, according to a government report made public on Monday.

articles.headline: Do Stockholders Really Know What’s Best?
articles.snippet: Kraft’s bid for Cadbury — and the ensuing outcry among shareholders — is Exhibit A in the argument that the notion of shareholder democracy isn’t all it’s cracked up to be.
articles.abstract: Kraft’s bid for Cadbury — and the ensuing outcry among shareholders — is Exhibit A in the argument that the notion of shareholder democracy isn’t all it’s cracked up to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: When news of Kraft’s hostile bid for Cadbury broke in England a couple of months back, it caused intense debate, including whether an American company should, by all rights, really be the new home of a well-known British brand that dates back to 1824.

articles.headline: Online Maps: Everyman Offers New Directions
articles.snippet: From Petaluma to Peshawar, volunteer cartographers are logging details of neighborhoods near and far.
articles.abstract: From Petaluma to Peshawar, volunteer cartographers are logging details of neighborhoods near and far.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  They don’t know it, but people who use Google’s online maps may be getting directions from Richard Hintz.

articles.headline: Paying Extra for Green Power, and Getting Ads Instead
articles.snippet: It is proving difficult to say exactly how customers’ voluntary payments for wind and solar power are actually used.
articles.abstract: It is proving difficult to say exactly how customers’ voluntary payments for wind and solar power are actually used.
articles.lead_paragraph: The solicitations have been flooding people’s mailboxes lately: pay a bit more on your electricity bill for 100 percent clean wind power. Or, the fliers say, buy “green power certificates” to offset your global warming emissions.

articles.headline: China Holds Firm on Major Issues in Obama’s Visit
articles.snippet: President Obama was confronted, on his first visit, with a fast-rising China more willing to say no to the U.S.
articles.abstract: President Obama was confronted, on his first visit, with a fast-rising China more willing to say no to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  In six hours of meetings, at two dinners and during a stilted 30-minute news conference in which President Hu Jintao did not allow questions, President Obama was confronted, on his first visit, with a fast-rising China more willing to say no to the United States.

articles.headline: 14,700 Disclosed Offshore Accounts
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. announced the number as it released the criteria to get names of account holders in a UBS tax case.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. announced the number as it released the criteria to get names of account holders in a UBS tax case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fear, apparently, can be a powerful inducement.
